👤 Lesson 8: Formal & Informal 'You'

In English, we use only one word – you – to talk to someone.

But in German, we have two forms:

  • du – informal you (used with friends, children)
  • Sie – formal you (used with strangers, elders, formal settings)

Sie (with capital S) works like a plural form and takes the same verb conjugation as sie (they).

🧠 Historical Tip

This concept existed in old/classical English too:

  • thou / thee – informal (like 'du')
  • you / ye – formal/plural (like 'Sie')

So English used to have the same distinction!

📖 Verb Conjugation Reminder

Here’s how 'you' forms change with the verb:

  • du kannst – you (informal) can
  • Sie können – you (formal) can

Example:

  • du spielst Cricket – you play cricket (informal)
  • Sie spielen Cricket – you play cricket (formal)

📌 Important Grammar Rule

In German, the conjugated verb always comes in the second position in a sentence.

This rule applies to statements and to W-questions.

❓ What are W-Fragen (W Questions)?

W-questions are question words that start with a 'W'. Here are the most common:

  • was – what
  • wann – when
  • wo – where
  • warum – why
  • wer – who
  • wie – how

Click 🔊 to hear how each question word sounds.

🧩 How to Form W-Fragen

2 Simple Rules:

  1. The W-word comes at the beginning
  2. The conjugated verb comes at second place

The verb still conjugates based on the subject (as we learned in Lesson 1).

  • ich trinke
  • du trinkst
  • er trinkt
  • wir trinken
  • sie / Sie trinken

🗣️ W-Fragen Examples (with 'Sie')

  • Was spielen Sie? – What do you play?
  • Wann spielen Sie Cricket? – When do you play cricket?
  • Warum spielen Sie Cricket? – Why do you play cricket?
  • Wer spielt Cricket? – Who plays cricket? (Note: wer is third person hence it is treared like Er/He)
  • Wie spielen Sie Cricket? – How do you play cricket?

🎁 Bonus Tip for Beginners

Use Sie instead of du as a beginner:

  • It's more polite
  • It always conjugates like sie (they) – which means verb stays in infinitive form + -en
  • Fewer forms to remember while learning!

Example: Sie trinken is used both for 'they drink' and 'you (formal) drink'

🎉 Lesson Complete!

Well done! You’ve now learned:

  • How to use du and Sie correctly
  • Why formal 'you' is easier for beginners
  • The structure of W-Fragen (what, when, where, etc.)
  • How to keep the conjugated verb in the second position

👉 You’re now ready to move on to exercises and start asking real questions in German!

Tip: Try using Sie in your daily German practice. It’s polite and simple to conjugate!
